fields.name: linker
fields.description:
queries the linker.
linker source is one of the LinkerSourceTypes,
id is the ID specific to the linked source

exclude is a list of resources you don't want returned in the response.
only is to include only one type of resource (should not conflict with exclude)

types.name: Boolean
types.description: The `Boolean` scalar type represents `true` or `false`.

types.name: Int
types.description: The `Int` scalar type represents non-fractional signed whole numeric values. Int can represent values between -(2^31) and 2^31 - 1.

types.name: StatePaginator
types.description: A paginated list of State items.

fields.name: paginatorInfo
fields.description: Pagination information about the list of items.

fields.name: data
fields.description: A list of State items.

types.name: PaginatorInfo
types.description: Pagination information about the corresponding list of items.

fields.name: count
fields.description: Total count of available items in the page.

fields.name: currentPage
fields.description: Current pagination page.

fields.name: firstItem
fields.description: Index of first item in the current page.

fields.name: hasMorePages
fields.description: If collection has more pages.

fields.name: lastItem
fields.description: Index of last item in the current page.

fields.name: lastPage
fields.description: Last page number of the collection.

fields.name: perPage
fields.description: Number of items per page in the collection.

fields.name: total
fields.description: Total items available in the collection.

fields.name: name

types.name: String
types.description: The `String` scalar type represents textual data, represented as UTF-8 character sequences. The String type is most often used by GraphQL to represent free-form human-readable text.

types.name: AWRegion
types.description: AW Maintain several regions. These are the abbreviations for them

enumValues.name: NT
enumValues.description: "North East

enumValues.name: MC
enumValues.description: MidAtlantic

enumValues.name: SE
enumValues.description: South East

enumValues.name: MW
enumValues.description: MidWest

enumValues.name: NW
enumValues.description: North West

enumValues.name: LP
enumValues.description: Lower Pacific

enumValues.name: WT
enumValues.description: West

enumValues.name: IN
enumValues.description: International -- identifies territories we care about, but ignore if domestic AW only

types.name: User

fields.name: uname
fields.description: User's login name

fields.name: email
fields.description: associated email

fields.name: image
fields.description: profile picture

fields.name: contact

fields.name: mobile_profile
fields.description: JSON object representing the User's mobile profile

fields.name: permissions
fields.description: permissions represent the groups and keys the user possesses

types.name: ID
types.description: The `ID` scalar type represents a unique identifier, often used to refetch an object or as key for a cache. The ID type appears in a JSON response as a String; however, it is not intended to be human-readable. When expected as an input type, any string (such as `"4"`) or integer (such as `4`) input value will be accepted as an ID.

types.name: ImageInfo
types.description: meta information on an image

fields.name: file_size
fields.description: filesize in bytes

types.name: ImageURI
types.description: urls to locate the three types of image

fields.name: medium
fields.description: typically around 800x600

fields.name: big
fields.description: unconstrained 1-2 MB per load

fields.name: thumb
fields.description: typically 100x200

types.name: Contact
types.description: Represents a contact, a user that can't login

fields.name: email
fields.description: associated email

fields.name: image
fields.description: profile picture

types.name: AWID
types.description: A type that allows a longish integer and a semi-numberic [A-Z][a-z][0-9] id

types.name: ArbitraryJSON
types.description: A type that allows a JSON in the definition. We use this for mobile profile, but will formalize it

types.name: EventNotification
types.description: Useful to retrieve the list of events the user has subscribed to

types.name: DateTimeISO8601
types.description: A ISO DateTimeISO8601 string with format `Y-m-d H:i:s` e.g. `2018-01-01T13:00:00Z`.

types.name: Point
types.description: Point which looks like two numbers 33.1 226.1

types.name: Date
types.description: A ISO Date string with format `Y-m-d` e.g. `2018-01-01`.

fields.name: batch_id
fields.description:
Batch ID represents one of a type -- like releases that are 600-800 cfs vs 800-1200 cfs, calendar displaying a
single event can color code based on batch_id

types.name: GaugeNotification
types.description: Useful to retrieve a list of gauges the user has subscribed to.

types.name: Gauge
types.description: This describes a Gauge

fields.name: id
fields.description: ID of the gauge, internal

fields.name: state
fields.description: #6-char state includes a CC-SSS country code then state code.

fields.name: source
fields.description: #gauge driver

fields.name: source_id
fields.description: #id within the gauge driver.

fields.name: name
fields.description: #name of the gauge

fields.name: huc
fields.description: USGS "HUC" the gauge is in

fields.name: loc
fields.description: gis wkb point where the gauge is

fields.name: timezone
fields.description: #tz database name (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tz_database)

fields.name: enabled
fields.description: see source (\App\Gauge), is this gauge enabled.

fields.name: updates
fields.description: last two updates in gauge update format.

types.name: GaugeUpdate
types.description: This describes a gauge update, a reading and when the reading was made

fields.name: metric
fields.description: metric structure

fields.name: obs_time
fields.description: #current update time

fields.name: obs_reading
fields.description: #current reading

fields.name: obs_data
fields.description: #misc structured data about the update

fields.name: lobs_time
fields.description: #last update

fields.name: lobs_reading
fields.description: #actual reading

types.name: GaugeReadingMetric
types.description: the thing we are measuring the gauge in (e.g. ft)

fields.name: id
fields.description: id of the metric, used everywhere you see metric_id

fields.name: shortkey
fields.description: quick way of refrencing the metric

fields.name: unit
fields.description: abbreviation of unit for humans (e.g. ft)

fields.name: name
fields.description: name if you need to describe it to a human (e.g. ft. stage)

fields.name: format
fields.description: format for a string format routine (e.g. js str.Format or sprintf)

types.name: Float
types.description: The `Float` scalar type represents signed double-precision fractional values as specified by [IEEE 754](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/IEEE_floating_point).

types.name: Reach
types.description: Represents a reach in the database

fields.name: id
fields.description: ID of reach (see getNextReachID query)

fields.name: river
fields.description: Name of the river

fields.name: section
fields.description: Name of the section

fields.name: altname
fields.description: Common name of the section

fields.name: county
fields.description: county name -- optional

fields.name: zipcode
fields.description: zip  -- optional

fields.name: length
fields.description: length in miles with fraction, mostly reported

fields.name: avggradient
fields.description: gradient in ft/mile, reported

fields.name: maxgradient
fields.description: max gradient in ft/mile, reported

fields.name: agency
fields.description: land agency name (if any) for adminstration of permits and land

fields.name: gaugeinfo
fields.description: paragraph explaining the gauges

fields.name: description
fields.description: multi paragraph explaining the section

fields.name: photo_id
fields.description: banner photo ID

fields.name: permitid
fields.description: permit id lookup

fields.name: huc
fields.description: HUC code drainage, will be assigned with proper location

fields.name: plat
fields.description: these are the calculated start and finish points of the reach, ploc and tloc are better

fields.name: skid
fields.description: last editor's ID

fields.name: status
fields.description: verfified (v) unverified (u) and "r" removed

fields.name: edited
fields.description: edited time/date

fields.name: is_final
fields.description: is this reach the current finalized reach (others represents prior or pending revisions)

fields.name: revision
fields.description: revision id

fields.name: class
fields.description: class of the river I-VI

fields.name: ploc
fields.description: putin location

fields.name: tloc
fields.description: takeout location

fields.name: was_final
fields.description: was this revision ever a final version (e.g. could it have been active in the past )

fields.name: thumboverride
fields.description: flag that was used indicate that the index image for the river should not be altered (e.g. use the raw/fullsize image)

fields.name: shuttledetails
fields.description: description of how to run the shuttle

fields.name: abstract
fields.description: short 1-2 sentence description of the reach used on hover on the map

fields.name: direction_default
fields.description: when we had routing, this would indicate the zip to show as the start (e.g. zip of the local town)

fields.name: custom_destination
fields.description: destination string when we had routing built into the app

fields.name: revision_comment
fields.description: comment left by the SK indicating what changed

fields.name: permiturl
fields.description: URL for signing up for a permit

fields.name: permitinfo
fields.description: paragraph on how to permit

fields.name: image_override
fields.description: when set to a non-zero indicates that the image should be used without scaling in the banner, may include a transform such as a zoom or crop in css transition tag format

fields.name: geom
fields.description: the actual linestring of the reach

fields.name: revisions
fields.description: all other reaches that came before, a list of prior versions of reach records

args.description: Limits number of fetched elements. Maximum allowed value: 2500.

fields.name: user
fields.description: indicates who was responsible for this revision

fields.name: last_warning
fields.description: last warning post on thre reach

fields.name: last_observation
fields.description: last gauge observation on the reach

fields.name: photo
fields.description: actual banner photo object of the reach

fields.name: sk
fields.description: indicates the SK that changd this

fields.name: permissions
fields.description: shows the permissions for the logged in user

fields.name: pending_events
fields.description: next event by category on the reach

types.name: ReachClass
types.description:
RapidClass
valid values: "I" , "I(II)" , "I(III)" , "I(IV)" , "I(V)" , "I(V+)" ,
   "I-II" , "I-II(III)" , "I-II(IV)" , "I-II(V)" , "I-II(V+)" , "II" ,
   "II(III)" , "II(IV)" , "II(V)" , "II(V+)" , "I-II+(III)" , "I-II+(IV)" , "I-II+(V)" , "I-II+(V+)" ,
   "II+" , "II+(III)" , "II+(IV)" , "II+(V)" , "II+(V+)" , "I-III" , "I-III(IV)" ,
   "I-III(V)" , "I-III(V+)" , "II-III" , "II-III(IV)" , "II-III(V)" , "II-III(V+)" , "III" ,
   "I-III+" , "I-III+(IV)" , "I-III+(V)" , "I-III+(V+)" , "II-III+" , "II-III+(IV)" , "II-III+(V)" ,
   "II-III+(V+)" , "III+" , "III+(IV)" , "III+(V)" , "III+(V+)" , "I-IV" , "I-IV(V)" ,
   "I-IV(V+)" , "II-IV" , "II-IV(V)" , "II-IV(V+)" , "III-IV" , "III-IV(V)" , "III-IV(V+)" , "IV" ,
   "IV(V)" , "IV(V+)" , "I-IV+" , "I-IV+(V)" , "I-IV+(V+)" , "II-IV+" , "II-IV+(V)" ,
   "II-IV+(V+)" , "III-IV+" , "III-IV+(V)" , "III-IV+(V+)" , "IV+" , "I-V" , "I-V(V+)" , "II-V" ,
   "II-V(V+)" , "III-V" , "III-V(V+)" , "IV-V" , "IV-V(V+)" , "V" ,
   "II-V+" , "III-V+" , "IV-V+" ,    "V+"

types.name: LineString
types.description: LineString looks like two numbers seperated by a space, and the tupels are seperated by comma so 10 30, 30 20, 10 -20.1

types.name: ReadingSummary
types.description:
Reading summary summarizes the running state of a reach,
it is a combination of a correlation and a physical gauge reading
with a gauge range

fields.name: id
fields.description: ID of the river summary

fields.name: gauge_reading
fields.description: gauge reading -- e.g. 88 of 88 cfs

fields.name: river_data
fields.description: misc river data, JSON format

fields.name: last_journal_update
fields.description: when correlation was written

fields.name: updated
fields.description: number of seconds since we have seen an update

fields.name: reading
fields.description:
actual reading recorded
		  - <0 too low
		  - 0-1 runnable
		  - >1 too high

fields.name: gauge_metric
fields.description: metric id for the gauge (e.g. 2=flow)

fields.name: last_gauge_reading
fields.description: last reading recorded

fields.name: last_gauge_updated
fields.description: last date of update

fields.name: gauge_comment
fields.description: comment about the gauge

fields.name: range_comment
fields.description: comment about the range (e.g. 'scrapy')

fields.name: gauge_perfect
fields.description: indicate if this is a perfect range

fields.name: gauge_estimated
fields.description: indicate approximation

fields.name: gauge_important
fields.description: indicate to emphasize this range

fields.name: adjusted_reach_class
fields.description: what is the class at this range

fields.name: rank
fields.description: order to consider this gauge in

fields.name: delay_update
fields.description: number of seconds to wait until we give up on this ranked gauge and display the next one down

fields.name: gauge_id
fields.description: the ID of the gauge we are tracking

types.description: A paginated list of Reach items.

types.name: POI
types.description:
POI is a Point-Of-Interest, usually and historically a rapid.
We have the idea of expanding this to pretty much any point that might need to be in a guidebook (e.g. putin, waterfall)

fields.name: id
fields.description: id used for updates

fields.name: name
fields.description: name of the feature (e.g. rapid name "Pillow Rapid")

fields.name: photo
fields.description: photo of the feature

fields.name: character
fields.description: list of attributes that can be used to describe this point

fields.name: distance
fields.description: distance in miles from the start of the river, used for sort

fields.name: difficulty
fields.description: difficulty of the rapid,

fields.name: description
fields.description: description of the rapid

fields.name: approximate
fields.description: approximate flag for distance

fields.name: rloc
fields.description: location

fields.name: permissions
fields.description: permissions for modifying by the current user

types.name: POIClass
types.description:
POIClass
valid values: 'N/A','I','II','II+','III','III+','IV','IV+','V','5.0','5.1','5.2','5.3','VI'

types.description: A paginated list of Accident items.

fields.name: paginatorInfo
fields.description: Pagination information about the list of items.

fields.name: data
fields.description: A list of Accident items.

types.name: GaugeSource
types.description: Describes a gauge source

fields.name: source
fields.description: specifies the source id

fields.name: title
fields.description: describes the source

fields.name: url
fields.description: references the URL of the source

fields.name: update_type
fields.description: update type describes the update strategy

fields.name: update_frequency
fields.description: update frequency in sconds

fields.name: update_start_time
fields.description: when updates are supposed to start

fields.name: data
fields.description: Used by the guage driver to store information about the gauge

fields.name: updated
fields.description: Last updated timestamp

fields.name: populated
fields.description: Last populated, IOW when the gauge checked for new gauges on the source

fields.name: disclaimer
fields.description: Disclaimer specific to the gauge source

types.name: GaugeUpdateType
types.description: Describes an update strategy

enumValues.name: READING
enumValues.description: Readings are queried periodically

enumValues.name: HEADER
enumValues.description: Source askes for all gauges updated since a given time

enumValues.name: MANUAL
enumValues.description: Source uses a different strategy

types.name: Time
types.description: A time string with format `H:i:s` e.g. `13:00:00`.

types.name: geobox
types.description: geographic area for a reach

types.description: A paginated list of Gauge items.

enumValues.name: L0
enumValues.description: no water what so ever

enumValues.name: L9
enumValues.description: Low, close to runnable but a boat couldn't get down

enumValues.name: R0
enumValues.description: Low scrapey

enumValues.name: R5
enumValues.description: Nice medium

enumValues.name: R9
enumValues.description: hardest, highest possible to run

enumValues.name: H0
enumValues.description: Not possible to boat,but close to boatable range

enumValues.name: H9
enumValues.description: floodier than flood

fields.name: gauge_comment
fields.description: comment about the gauge

fields.name: range_comment
fields.description: comment about the range (e.g. 'scrapy')

fields.name: gauge_perfect
fields.description: indicate if this is a perfect range

fields.name: gauge_estimated
fields.description: indicate approximation

fields.name: gauge_important
fields.description: indicate to emphasize this range

fields.name: adjusted_reach_class

fields.name: gauge_id

fields.name: source
fields.description: the gauge id that gets the update

fields.name: target

fields.name: time_adjustment

fields.name: metric
fields.description: metric to watch

fields.name: estimated
fields.description: is the value estimated? indicated in the UI usually with a ~ so like ~7ft.

fields.name: id
fields.description: id of correlation

fields.name: user
fields.description: UID that made the correlation

fields.name: excluded
fields.description: exclude from the gauge summary, but shows in detail

fields.name: delay_update
fields.description:
when reporting a reading, wait this long in seconds before assuming the primary gauge is down.
		this is a bit like a rank. 0 is default, but if you have two 0 correlation headers you will get
		two gauges that will report the last-updated, that is fine for two sources for the same reading, but
		if you have a primary gauge, make it zero, and then a secondary that you want to report if the
		primary gauge hasn't reported in 4 hours, set this to 4*60*60. If you have a third gauge that you want
		to report only after a day then use 24*60*60. The reported value will be the most recent one, so this
		only affects ranking.

fields.name: id
fields.description: ID of this header

fields.name: min
fields.description: min value in range

fields.name: max
fields.description: max value in range

fields.name: user
fields.description: user writing this

fields.name: perfect
fields.description: perfect range, marked on ranges where the river is perfect, UI displays thumbs-up

fields.name: important
fields.description: important comment on this range, marked for ranges where emphasizing the comment is important

fields.name: range_min
fields.description:
min range, on a simple gauge R0
gauge range representing the bottom of this range, example is if a river has a perfect middle range, so
0-200 is OK, 200-300 is perfect, 300-900 is fine, create three correlation ranges like so:
R0-R3 0-200, R3-R6 200-300 perfect, R6-R9 300-900 important "has killed people"

fields.name: range_max
fields.description: range_max, on a simple gauge R9

fields.name: adjusted_reach_class
fields.description: if the reach class changes, display this as difficulty for the range.

fields.name: range_comment
fields.description: range comment, to display as info on the range

fields.name: articleUpdate
fields.description: write an article

fields.name: userUpdate
fields.description: updates a user record, at this point to attach mobile information (see UserInput)

fields.name: directoryContactUpdate
fields.description: add a user id (ID) to a listing, listings will allow users to sign up to certain groups, this will fail if the non-admin to a non-public group

fields.name: directoryContactDelete
fields.description: remove a user id from a listing and area (e.g. "sk","123" to remove stream team privs)

fields.name: postUpdate
fields.description: send a post up with a UUID

fields.name: photoUpdate
fields.description: send a photo record up record, file is sent with photoFileUpdate with appropriate section and section_id

fields.name: photoFileUpdate
fields.description: associate a photo with a section and section ID, typically this will be a POST with a post id of the container

args.name: id
args.description: UUID of existing or new photo file

fields.name: poiUpdate
fields.description: updates or creates a rapid with a UUID given

args.name: id
args.description: when specified id will identify the POI to update, when omitted it will create a POI

args.name: poi
args.description: POI, if omitted the field will default to existing

fields.name: reachUpdate
fields.description: updates or creates a reach with a ID (from nextReachID) given

args.name: id
args.description: ID is numeric (nextReachID query), when omitted this will create a reach

args.name: reach
args.description: reach input has fields to update, when omitted they will default in create, or not update in update

fields.name: poiDelete
fields.description: removes a POI

args.name: id
args.description: id to update

fields.name: reachDelete
fields.description: remove/delist a reach

args.name: id
args.description: id to remove

fields.name: gaugeCorrelationUpdate
fields.description: updates or creates a rapid with a UUID given

fields.name: gaugeCorrelationRangeUpdate
fields.description: updates or creates a rapid with a UUID given

Attaches an arbitrary JSON object to a user

inputFields.description: how is flow estimated, stage? relative can be simply

inputFields.name: observation

By itself, if you add this to target a river gauge,
you will get a link between the source id and the river. In that case it should show a listing.
If you add ranges then you will get interpretations of the gauge.

inputFields.name: delay_update
inputFields.description:
when reporting a reading, wait this long in seconds before assuming the primary gauge is down.
		this is a bit like a rank. 0 is default, but if you have two 0 correlation headers you will get
		two gauges that will report the last-updated, that is fine for two sources for the same reading, but
		if you have a primary gauge, make it zero, and then a secondary that you want to report if the
		primary gauge hasn't reported in 4 hours, set this to 4*60*60. If you have a third gauge that you want
		to report only after a day then use 24*60*60. The reported value will be the most recent one, so this
		only affects ranking.

types.name: __Schema
types.description: A GraphQL Schema defines the capabilities of a GraphQL server. It exposes all available types and directives on the server, as well as the entry points for query, mutation, and subscription operations.

fields.name: types
fields.description: A list of all types supported by this server.

fields.name: queryType
fields.description: The type that query operations will be rooted at.

fields.name: mutationType
fields.description: If this server supports mutation, the type that mutation operations will be rooted at.

fields.name: subscriptionType
fields.description: If this server support subscription, the type that subscription operations will be rooted at.

fields.name: directives
fields.description: A list of all directives supported by this server.

types.name: __Type
types.description:
The fundamental unit of any GraphQL Schema is the type. There are many kinds of types in GraphQL as represented by the `__TypeKind` enum.

Depending on the kind of a type, certain fields describe information about that type. Scalar types provide no information beyond a name and description, while Enum types provide their values. Object and Interface types provide the fields they describe. Abstract types, Union and Interface, provide the Object types possible at runtime. List and NonNull types compose other types.

types.name: __TypeKind
types.description: An enum describing what kind of type a given `__Type` is.

enumValues.name: SCALAR
enumValues.description: Indicates this type is a scalar.

enumValues.name: OBJECT
enumValues.description: Indicates this type is an object. `fields` and `interfaces` are valid fields.

enumValues.name: INTERFACE
enumValues.description: Indicates this type is an interface. `fields` and `possibleTypes` are valid fields.

enumValues.name: UNION
enumValues.description: Indicates this type is a union. `possibleTypes` is a valid field.

enumValues.name: ENUM
enumValues.description: Indicates this type is an enum. `enumValues` is a valid field.

enumValues.name: INPUT_OBJECT
enumValues.description: Indicates this type is an input object. `inputFields` is a valid field.

enumValues.name: LIST
enumValues.description: Indicates this type is a list. `ofType` is a valid field.

enumValues.name: NON_NULL
enumValues.description: Indicates this type is a non-null. `ofType` is a valid field.

types.name: __Field
types.description: Object and Interface types are described by a list of Fields, each of which has a name, potentially a list of arguments, and a return type.

types.name: __InputValue
types.description: Arguments provided to Fields or Directives and the input fields of an InputObject are represented as Input Values which describe their type and optionally a default value.

fields.name: defaultValue
fields.description: A GraphQL-formatted string representing the default value for this input value.

types.name: __EnumValue
types.description: One possible value for a given Enum. Enum values are unique values, not a placeholder for a string or numeric value. However an Enum value is returned in a JSON response as a string.

types.name: __Directive
types.description:
A Directive provides a way to describe alternate runtime execution and type validation behavior in a GraphQL document.

In some cases, you need to provide options to alter GraphQL's execution behavior in ways field arguments will not suffice, such as conditionally including or skipping a field. Directives provide this by describing additional information to the executor.

types.name: __DirectiveLocation
types.description: A Directive can be adjacent to many parts of the GraphQL language, a __DirectiveLocation describes one such possible adjacencies.

enumValues.name: QUERY
enumValues.description: Location adjacent to a query operation.

enumValues.name: MUTATION
enumValues.description: Location adjacent to a mutation operation.

enumValues.name: SUBSCRIPTION
enumValues.description: Location adjacent to a subscription operation.

enumValues.name: FIELD
enumValues.description: Location adjacent to a field.

enumValues.name: FRAGMENT_DEFINITION
enumValues.description: Location adjacent to a fragment definition.

enumValues.name: FRAGMENT_SPREAD
enumValues.description: Location adjacent to a fragment spread.

enumValues.name: INLINE_FRAGMENT
enumValues.description: Location adjacent to an inline fragment.

enumValues.name: VARIABLE_DEFINITION
enumValues.description: Location adjacent to a variable definition.

enumValues.name: SCHEMA
enumValues.description: Location adjacent to a schema definition.

enumValues.name: SCALAR
enumValues.description: Location adjacent to a scalar definition.

enumValues.name: OBJECT
enumValues.description: Location adjacent to an object type definition.

enumValues.name: FIELD_DEFINITION
enumValues.description: Location adjacent to a field definition.

enumValues.name: ARGUMENT_DEFINITION
enumValues.description: Location adjacent to an argument definition.

enumValues.name: INTERFACE
enumValues.description: Location adjacent to an interface definition.

enumValues.name: UNION
enumValues.description: Location adjacent to a union definition.

enumValues.name: ENUM
enumValues.description: Location adjacent to an enum definition.

enumValues.name: ENUM_VALUE
enumValues.description: Location adjacent to an enum value definition.

enumValues.name: INPUT_OBJECT
enumValues.description: Location adjacent to an input object type definition.

enumValues.name: INPUT_FIELD_DEFINITION
enumValues.description: Location adjacent to an input object field definition.

types.name: Region
types.description: Used to query regions

types.name: GaugeCorrelationRangeInput
types.description: Adds a range to interpret running or not running to a correlation

inputFields.name: id
inputFields.description: ID of this header

inputFields.name: min
inputFields.description: min value in range

inputFields.name: max
inputFields.description: max value in range

inputFields.name: uid
inputFields.description: user writing this

inputFields.name: perfect
inputFields.description: perfect range, marked on ranges where the river is perfect, UI displays thumbs-up

inputFields.name: important
inputFields.description: important comment on this range, marked for ranges where emphasizing the comment is important

inputFields.name: range_min
inputFields.description:
min range, on a simple gauge R0
gauge range representing the bottom of this range, example is if a river has a perfect middle range, so
0-200 is OK, 200-300 is perfect, 300-900 is fine, create three correlation ranges like so:
R0-R3 0-200, R3-R6 200-300 perfect, R6-R9 300-900 important "has killed people"

inputFields.name: range_max
inputFields.description: range_max, on a simple gauge R9

inputFields.name: adjusted_reach_class
inputFields.description: if the reach class changes, display this as difficulty for the range.

inputFields.name: range_comment
inputFields.description: range comment, to display as info on the range

inputFields.name: correlation_id
inputFields.description: ID of the header

types.name: PageInfo
types.description: Pagination information about the corresponding list of items.

fields.name: hasNextPage
fields.description: When paginating forwards, are there more items?

fields.name: hasPreviousPage
fields.description: When paginating backwards, are there more items?

fields.name: startCursor
fields.description: When paginating backwards, the cursor to continue.

fields.name: endCursor
fields.description: When paginating forwards, the cursor to continue.

fields.name: total
fields.description: Total number of node in connection.

fields.name: count
fields.description: Count of nodes in current request.

fields.name: currentPage
fields.description: Current page of request.

fields.name: lastPage
fields.description: Last page in connection.

types.name: OrderByClause
types.description: Allows ordering a list of records.

inputFields.name: field
inputFields.description: The column that is used for ordering.

inputFields.name: order
inputFields.description: The direction that is used for ordering.

types.name: Trashed
types.description: Specify if you want to include or exclude trashed results from a query.

enumValues.name: ONLY
enumValues.description: Only return trashed results.

enumValues.name: WITH
enumValues.description: Return both trashed and non-trashed results.

enumValues.name: WITHOUT
enumValues.description: Only return non-trashed results.

directives.name: include
directives.description: Directs the executor to include this field or fragment only when the `if` argument is true.

args.name: if
args.description: Included when true.

directives.name: skip
directives.description: Directs the executor to skip this field or fragment when the `if` argument is true.

args.name: if
args.description: Skipped when true.

directives.name: deprecated
directives.description: Marks an element of a GraphQL schema as no longer supported.

args.name: reason
args.description: Explains why this element was deprecated, usually also including a suggestion for how to access supported similar data. Formatted in [Markdown](https://daringfireball.net/projects/markdown/).
